title: 108_s2353
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Geologic Mapping Reauthorization Act of 2004". The National Geologic Mapping Act of 1992 is amended to address the lack of modern, digital geologic maps for 75% of the United States. Amendments include changes to planning and identifying processes. The National Geologic Mapping Act of 1992 is amended to improve recreation and public awareness, and to make geologic maps more available by updating planning processes. The National Geologic Mapping Act of 1992 is amended to change "protection" to "management" in Section 2(b, and set deadlines for actions by the United States Geological Survey in Section 4. Section 4 of the National Geologic Mapping Act of 1992 is amended to set deadlines for actions by the United States Geological Survey, requiring submissions within specific timeframes after the enactment of the National Geologic Mapping Reauthorization Act of 2004. SEC. 5 amends the objectives of the geologic mapping program, while SEC. 6 modifies the components, including addressing the needs of land management agencies. SEC. 7 establishes a geologic mapping advisory committee. Section 5(a) of the National Geologic Mapping Act of 1992 is amended to change the designated officials and consultation process. Section 5(a) of the National Geologic Mapping Act of 1992 is amended to change the designated officials and consultation process by adjusting the roles and number of representatives from the private sector. SEC. 8 of the National Geologic Mapping Act of 1992 is amended to specify functions of the National Geologic-Map Database, including information on obtaining geologic maps and funding under the national cooperative geologic mapping program. SEC. 9 requires a biennial report. SEC. 9 of the National Geologic Mapping Act of 1992 is amended to require a biennial report, with the deadline set at 3 years after the enactment of the National Geologic Mapping Reauthorization Act of 2004 and biennially thereafter. SEC. 10 of the National Geologic Mapping Act of 1992 authorizes $64,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2010. Amendments include increasing the deadline for biennial reports to 3 years after the enactment of the National Geologic Mapping Reauthorization Act of 2004.
